Award.AwardTitle: CC*DNI Campus Design: Northern's Network Expansion for Large Science and Engineering Data Flows

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Northern New Mexico College (Northern) is establishing a dedicated research network fabric and Science DMZ that is: 1) connecting multiple teaching and research laboratories serving biology, chemistry, environmental science, and engineering; and 2) improving the capacity and efficiency of moving Terabytes (TBs) of data sets.

The proposed network upgrades are permitting faculty and students to engage in high-throughput data analysis research. High-speed switches are allowing TBs of data transfers from storage nodes to multiple labs, including solar energy variables needed to analyze irradiance and solar power generation patterns; data sets of 3-D convection simulation computed by Northern's Aguila parallel Supercomputer; and TBs of ribonucleic acid (RNA) sequencing needed to understand the role of Cajal Bodies in the biogenesis of non-coding RNA in land plants.

Northern serves a 72% Hispanic and 11% Native American student population. Northern?s recent development of Engineering, Biology, and Environmental Science programs has greatly increased access to four-year STEM degrees for northern New Mexicans. This CC*DNI project represents the next step in closing the STEM education gap that prevents Hispanics, the fastest growing ethnic group in the nation's labor force, and Native Americans from entering STEM professions. The remote experimental control features to lab equipment are also addressing the geographic challenge of campus access for students living in remote mountain villages, especially during winter months, and is allowing for the development of remote undergraduate research experiences known to support the success of minority populations studying STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Establishing a Research Network and Science DMZ

The major goal of this project was to establish a dedicated research network and Science DMZ. The new cyberinfrastructure connects multiple buildings with the Information Technology (IT) datacenter and the central Storage Area Network (SAN) via new 10 Gbps single-mode fibers. The Science DMZ includes data transfer nodes (DTNs), performance monitoring (perfSONAR) and metering points, and new security capability amenable for large flows. The research network enhances the capacity and efficiency of moving large data sets, which enables the expansion of data intensive research and education projects at Northern New Mexico College (NNMC).


Fostering Undergraduate Research 

The number of undergraduate research experiences in areas where big data is prevalent, such as biology and bioinformatics, has increased rapidly. Just few years ago, NNMC had no capacity to establish research experiences with large data sets (no storage units nor network capacity for large flows). In 2010, only two summer research experiences were conducted on campus. By 2017, the number of research experiences in biology alone increased to almost 20 students per summer. The deployment of single-mode fibers and SAN facilitates and increases the research output and quality of education in STEM fields. During the last year, NNMC students obtained honorific mentions and first place awards in research projects related to bioinformatics and big data. Moreover, students now have job opportunities and are admitted to graduate schools at an increased rate. Until 2005, NNMC was a community college. Today, NNMC produces quality research while carrying a dual mission of community college and four-year institution.The teaching and research activities enabled by this project have enhanced the preparation of minority populations to enter professions critical to the nation. More than 70% of the affected population is Hispanic and 10% is Native American.  

Strengthening Relation with Los Alamos National Laboratory and Developing the Workforce

Undergraduate students played a key role in the project. The project represented a hands-on training opportunity for several students, whose expertise in the cyberinfrastructure (high-speed routing, switching, cybersecurity, data transfer tools, and monitoring for Science DMZ) was developed through the project. Their knowledge and skills led them to apply for positions at Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL), where they are currently staff members. NNMC and LANL have strengthened the partnership to fill the demand for IT professionals. The two institutions are actively encouraging students to apply for student intern positions and summer internships. By 2018, it is expected that 20 students will follow this career path. The collaboration was also extended to instruction, where one staff member from LANL has committed to teach a regular semester-long course in the Information Engineering Technology (IET) program at NNMC. 

Improving WAN Connectivity

This project constituted the catalyst to improve the Wide Area Network (WAN) connectivity from 100 Mbps to 1 Gbps. This improvement is the result of the research experiences on big data conducted by faculty and students. There is an increasing collaboration with national universities and institutions, such as University of New Mexico, University of Texas at El Paso, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, and National Center for Genome Resources. Data obtained from instruments located in collaborator networks will be transferred to NNMC more efficiently.
